text:
33cl bottle, Alko. 
The beer pours mahogany color, thin white head. 
Nutty, bready, mämmi aroma and flavor. Heavy malty and nutty indeed. 
Rye, liquid bread, hops, molasses. Medium to full bodied. Long finish of bread and caramel. Tasty bock.

Bottle, alko kyrkslätt. Dark brown clear. Malty, doughy smooth bready nose, light roast, dark doughy like. Med full bodied, light metallics. Flavourful, nice sweetness, bitters balance, some chocolate in finish. Quite ok.

(Bottle, 0.33 l - BB date unreadable, from Alko, 20170609) The beer poured dark brown and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had malts, molasses and cocoa. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, molasses, grass, chocolate and bitterness. Aftertaste was malty and bitter. A beer having good characteristics but the end result was unbalanced.

Bottle. Clear mahogny brown in color with a tan head. Sweetness, bready dark malts and cocoa powder in aroma. Bready malty taste as well, mild bitterness in the background. Sweetness too, not too much though.

A dark, reddish borwn beer, a head is small and light beige. Aroma has dried fruits with plums, some breadyness, maltyness with honey. Quite sweet aroma. Taste has dried fruitness, honey, only light breadyness, quite sweet. Medium bodied, smooth enough. Quite tasteful beer, dried fruits and only light breadyness.

Bottle shared thanks to my brother. Clear amber with small beige head. Light cardboard, pils malts, caramel, light dried fruit, soft earthy notes. Medium sweet and light bitter. Over medium bodied with soft feel.

From old tasting notes. Translucent reddish brown color. Tan head that dissapates quickly. Intense smoky, sweet roasted malt nose. Full roasted malt flavor is sweet at first, the becoming tangy, then bitter in finish. Long bittersweet aftertaste.very big and full-bodied with a chewy mouthfeel.
Flaske. Aromaen er karamell, gress og noe tørkede mørke frukter. Smaken er søt malt med noe gress og urter fra humlen. Bitter ettersmak.
Bottle. Copper colour with white head. Fruity, nut and caramel aroma. Sweet, fruity, nuts, malt, caramel taste. Some bread. Medium body.

Pours dark copper with small lacing. Aroma suggests caramel and toasted malt flavour. Tastewise, mostly semi sweet caramel and traces of some fruit. Finish is slightly bitter, long. High drinkability for any occasion. Medium body, carbonation is soft.

Draft @ Gummibaren, Drammen.
Cuivrée, col fin beige.
Arôme au nez malté, léger caramel avec un petit rétro épicé me rappelant la cannelle.
Palais est un peu plus imposant avec ses quasi 7%, un peu sec avec un côté fruité noir et une touche dépice de cannelle. Malt modéré versant sur du Munich et pâle.
God å drikke kan oxo fint brukes i pannekaker . Synd ikke alle polutsalg har den

Aroma : caramel, chocolate, 
Appearance: red/brown, clear, white foam, minimal head, 
Taste : medium sweetness, medium sourness, 
The palate: medium body, sticky, average carbonation, long finish, bitter,

Clear chestnut colour liquid with yellowish head. Aroma of malts, caramel, saurkraut. Taste is same but less, light sweet, medium bitter, light sour. Light body, creamy feel, average carbonisation, astringent

Bottle from Rune and Finn (thank you!) passed on at the NWAF, Derby, Friday, 19th February 2016 shared at dads house, Kilburn, Derbyshire.   Pours reddy amber with a white/off-white head, slightly sour on the nose. Some toffee, fruity with some berries, its a busy carbonation, tangy but also a bit sour in the mouth, not sure if this is intentional and yet I dont mind it, but it certainly moves this away from a traditional Bock. Yes it is quite gassy, its fine.  A6 A4 T6 P3 Ov12 3.1
Klart mahognibrunt med tynt, hvitt skum. Tørket frukt, kaffe og toffee i duften. Mye det samme i smaken sammen med maltekstrakt. Lett bitterhet i avslutningen. Litt tynn munnfølelse.

Amber brown toward copper colour with an off-white head.
Nose: Moderate maltiness, caramel, hints of dried fruits and a little fruity hops.
Taste: Medium light bodied, rather fruity bock. Slight sweetness, rather rich carbonation. The hops shows up in a little bitterness in the aftertaste.
Malty, balanced, smooth and rather elegant albeit a bit one dimensional. But it slowly grows on me...
Rated from old notes. Pours with an airy creamy head. Fruity, sweet and full with an appropriate alcohol presence. Mildly bitter. Nice.

8/17/2007 10:31:39 AM Bottle at Tronds house. Dark ruby colour. Lasting head. Sweet. Caramel. Malty. Slightly spicy. One of the smoothest bocks Ive ever tasted - very different from the Benelux variety. Watery and nowhere near as spicy as what I am used to - but good nonetheless. Also another MJ entrant.

Norwegian import at The New Penguin, January 2015. Vanilla capped burgundy appearing darker. Enticing chewy aroma of malt loaf; juicy fig and prune, cherry Tunes, muscovado. Brown sugar and malt heavy with good chewy malt loaf studded with raisin and dried strawberry bits. Slightly saline and beefy. Dark chocolate and wholemeal hints. A touch tooth-rotting but good.
Pours copper color, nice beige head, good lacing. Atlroma of caramel, bread crust, dried plums. Taste medium sweet, caramel, fruits. Very decent bock

An overall nice beer, rather heavy taste but light aroma. Nice with the gruyere cheese

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nice looking tall 0,33 l bottle bought at Grüne Woche 2015, Berlin. Pours out dark red brown with a one finger light tanned head. Malt, berriefruits and choco on the nose. Taste starts smooth malty with coffie, berriefuits, sweet, alcoholic hints. Little bit dry ending. A nice no. 700 for me.
How: Bottle Appearance: Dark brown, medium head. Aroma: chocolate, caramel, wood. Palate: medium body, soft carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2014 Bottle at Nathalia & Andreas Christmas Lunch. Clear dark brown - white head. High sweetness. Candy. Burned sugar. Roasted. Lots of burned caramel. Light light acid notes. Thin body with a sweet finish.

Looks; near clear dark brown body, tall tan head, slim lacing lines all over.
Aroma; dark sweet malts, lots of dark fruits, raisins, prunes, toffee caramel.
 	Taste; dark caramel malts, prunes in chocolate sauce, raisins in creamy syrup, milky toffee fudges.
Feels soft as tart cream in the mouth, superb! Finishes sweet creamy, with chocolate and caramels on the backbone of roasted sweet malts.	Overall; splendid evening sipper.

From bottle 15.10.14. Dark copper. Dark beige head and lacing. Aroma of dark caramel, sweet malt, dark berries and fine port. Similar taste, with prunes, dates and dark rye bread. High drinkability. A superb bock!

0,33 l, flaske, BB 13/12/13, gave fra Handschuh - tak! 1. oktober 2014.
Flot mahognifarvet norsk Dunkler Bock med mindre offwhite skumtop, 1-2 cm.
Syrlig og sødlig aroma af ristet malt. Noter af blomme, chokolade og en form for bondegårdsaroma. 
Virkelig god og dyb smag omend lidt vandet i konsistensen. Dejlig balance. En anelse syrlig i starten af smagsbilledet og derefter indtræder den gode balance mellem sødmen og det bitre. God smag fra den brændte/ristede malt. 
Middel krop og fin karbonering en anelse under middel giver en blød rar mundfølelse uden at være for flad. Konsistensen er som nævnt en anelse vandet uden at være for tynd. 
Første gang jeg blev præsenteret for Aass' Bock, var jeg ganske imponeret, og den svigter ikke mine forventninger.
Bottle at beer festival. Poured a clear dark red with a white head. Slightly hoppy and airily sweet on the nose. Hints of syrupy sweetness with slight bubbles and bitterness. Good.
Dark brown, small light brown head. Sweet aroma with caramel, clear malty taste, but good balance.
33cl bottle. Dark red colour with large beige head. New designed bottle and label. Looking good. Caramel aroma. Kinda sweet. Low bitterness. Nice brew from Aass.
Dark bronze colour, tan head. Lightly smoked caramel malts, some saltiness and nuts. Taste has an initial sweetness, with light bitterness throughout. Medium carbonation.

Deep red-brown color, beige head. Roasted malt nose, caramel, hints of nuts and oak. Sweet, candi sugar taste, dried fruit, roasted malt, hint of chocolate. Oily texture, medium body, soft carbonation.
Duft av humle, malt og krydder. Mørk rødvins farge. Lite skum, noe brunt langs kant. God smak av krydder, frukt og malt.
Rødbrun klar i fargen med beige lavt skum. Malt, kandis og karamellukt. Mild bitter litt søt smak. Kort ettersmak. Lite kullsyre.
Klar mørk rødbrun farve med beige skum. Lukt av malt, karamell og frukt. Smak av malt, kaffe, karamell og frukt. Vinmonopolet.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2015 Brown color.  Medium carbonation.  A little sweet, touches of caramel, baked bread, tiniest hint of fruit. Very smooth, malt forward beer.  No hop flavor or aroma.Tastes of biscuits (of the brittish variety), nuts, caramel, touch of milk chocolate and coffee.  Delicious bock...lacks the sharp bite of many of the style.

Bottle at home. Has a clear deep reddish brown colour with a beige and medium head. The aroma contains a lot of dried fruit, plums and oak. The flavour is sweet with the addition of cocoa and brown sugar. Has a light and slick mouth feel, and a light bitterness. A nice and well balanced bock.
Pours clear dark red-brown with beige head. Aroma is malty and dried fruits, rasin. Flavour follows the nose, with coffee and sweet caramell. Nice warming, bitter finish. Very good!
Pretty good beer. Quite bitter, I guess this is both from hops and malts, and in general and total it tastes great and refreshing.

Bottle from VM. Dark brown with High head. Malty sweat some Chocolate aroma. Round Light sweetness and bitterness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Vinmonopolet Manglerud enjoyed at home
Pours dark brown with a dense beige head. Smells of caramel, malts, hint of chocolate and roast. Moderate to medium sweet, clean, hints of roast, nice caramel flavors, also hints of nuts. Moderate bitter finish. A very nice dunkler bock. I liked this years ago, and it still is quite good

Bottle 33cl. Small off white head disappearing. Dark caramel color. Not too much carbonation, but some small bubbles there. Aroma is caramel, gingerbread, prunes and port. Taste is like a sugary coffee liquer.
0.33l bottle. Brown body, light brown head. Aroma of caramel, ripe figs and a bit of roastyness and honey. Taste of caramel and figs with some roastyness. Decent beer.

While the aroma and the aftertaste are all very very pleasant, this one leaves a lot to be desired. Almost watery with next to nothing sticking to the palate. True, the remnants of sweet chocolate hang out a while, but even that is faint. I prefer deeper more aggressive bocks. Still the tastiest Aass Ive ever drank.

Bottle - 330ml. Dark copper body with a thin off-white foamy head. Good malty/hoppy aroma with cinnamon and brown sugar hints. Taste carries oaky, and brown sugar notes. Ends with a moderately warming finish. Decent Bock.

0,33 bottle kvadrat. Creamy light brown head. A nice maltcharacter in the nose, some chocolate, some smoked malt. Taste is some sweetnesss with bitterness in the end. A suprisingly good bock even if im not a bockperson.

Bottle @ Christers. Pours dark brown with a creamy offwhite head. Aroma of roasted malt, bread, dark caramel, brown sugar, wood. Flavor is sweet with malt, bread, oak, brown sugar. Medium body, lively carbonation, quite sweet finish. 041212
Bottle @ Aarhus tasting. Clear reddish brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and bready. Flavor is quite sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish. 041212
Bottle, 6.5%. Dark brown with small beige head. Aroma is malt, caramel, bread, chocolate and nutty. Flavour is malt, chocolate, nutty, medium sweet, dark fruits, hop, bread and a little bitter.
Bottle. Nice creamy head with good excellent duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are sweet caramel, bread, malt, syrup and hops. Quite sweet.

Bottle. Dark mahogany brown colour, with medium big creamy, light brown head, that sits down slowly. Light aroma of burnt  malts and dark chocolate. Medium to full body, taste goes from light sweet into a moderate bitter with strong chocolate notes.

330 ml bottle @ home November 27,2012.Bought at Vinmonopolet Majorstuen,Oslo.Served in a tulip glass.Brown to copper in color.Aroma is malt and fruits.Sweet and nice Bock Beer.Superb with port wine on the side.My favorite Bock Beer in Norway.

330 ml bottle. BB 28/03/13. (Vinmonopolet) Mo i Rana, Norway.
Dark coppery red colour with small creamy light tan head.
Dark malt, dark fruits and some sweetness in aroma.
Flavour is strong malt, dark fruits and alcohol.
Nice old fashioned label. This lacks the kick.

Oerland bottle. Brownish-amber pour with a big fluffy white head. Lots of malt and a little molasses in the aroma. Pretty bold flavor with caramel malt and just a hint of bitterness. This was pretty tasty.

33cl bottle from Vinmonopolet. Pours dark amber with a tan head. Malty and caramelly aroma with some roasted notes and hints of dark fruits. Sweet and caramelly with balanced bitterness. Quite nice autumn beer.

Liquor store in Voss: Pours a brownish head with a quickly dissipating beige head. Aroma is liqueur and dark fruit. Taste is somewhat sweet, but there is something mitigating that as well. There is some complexity. The body is medium. I suppose this does what it can  with the style.

Bottle at home. Dark brown color, low light brown head.
Malty nose with caramel, nuts and fruit. Caramel taste with sugar and chocolate, thick body, long dry malty ending. A good bock

16/01 0.5 l bottle courtesy of Marko, thanks for sharing! It poured clear brownish body with medium sized head. Sweet caramel and other malt aroma, weaker grainy notes. Quite sweet flavor, simple caramel and sugar with coffee that doesnt balance it much. Medium bodied with very sweet finish. Slightly alcoholic as well, which should not be for such ABV. Expected much more from this renowned beer.
Bottle.  Clear dark amber color, medium off white head.  Aroma of burnt toast and caramel.  Taste is sweet and nutty.  Nice stuff.
In my opinion one of the best Norwegian bock beers, with a good balance of caramel, dried fruits and coffee flavours and a pleasant hint of hops in the background.

Dark amber colour with a light beige head. Caramel and some fruity notes in the aroma. A solid sweet malty background with some roasted malt, and a light fruitiness.Bottle from Vinmonopolet in Halden, Norway
cereal, roasty, spruce, herbs, basement aromas, licorice, smoke, brown, sparkling, brown foam, heavy cloying sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, full body, soft carbonation,

Bottle brought from Oslo by a friend, huge thanks Sara! Small off white dark amber-red. Sweet, sourish heavy malty nose, maybe light alcohol. Nice sweet coffeeish taste, sweeter than expected but hardly bad. Nicely bready. Maaaybe vague alcohol in the background. Pleasant and drinkable.

Bottle. Dark amber, small to average and fully diminishing light brown head. Moderate, malty and sweetish aroma, some caramel and light roasted malt. Body is medium, malty and sweetish flavor, caramel and some roasted malt with some dark bread. Finish is average, malty and sweetish, caramel and light roasted malt with dark bread, light alcohol. Sweetish bock with some caramel.

0.33l bottle. This is a clear light dark brown body with a thin sidesticking off-white head. Aroma is light sweet with some dark caramel, thin fruity hints and perhaps even some raisins. Average carbonation, medium to full-bodied and it has a light sticky to oily mouthfeel. Flavors are also mildly sweet with lots of dark caramel, more of those raisins, something mildly burned and just that little prickling and warming boozy alcohol touch in the finish. All in all a light drinkable bock (I even got my girlfriend to drink this and shes not the kind who normally drinks bocks) This has to be one of the best Ive ever had from Aass.

Pours a copper color with a beige-white head. Aroma of bread, caramel, dried fruit and some alcohol. Flavour is rather sweet with caramel, bread, sugar, dried fruit and some warming alcohol. Rather smooth wit soft carbonation. Medium bodied.
Ruby brown colour with a lasting off-white head. Aroma of bready malt, slightly toasted and with a fruity note. Sweetish malt and toffee flavour with fruity character
Pours copper with a beige head. Aroma is roasted caramel and dried fruit. Flavour is roasted caramel, breaddy notes and dried fruit.

Pours a clear and dark brown beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, caramel, fruit, dried fruit and notes of bread. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness. Overall an average beer.

Bottle.

Clear dark red/brown with a small creamy head. Aroma and taste of malt, caramel, brown sugar and some dark fruit. On the thin side with a soft carbonation.

Pours deep brown, caramel, with a hint of red. Almost none, but tan, head. Smell of bread and burnt malt. Sweet, some sense of alcohol. Aroma of bread and burnt malt. Some caramel. Feels actually a bit fizzy.

BB 12/11. Bottle @ Odense Tasting, June 2011. Thanks to ClubGonzo. Pours clear amber with a small creamy white head. Bread, fruit and caramel. Medium bodied. Very simple - vaguely oxidized feel though.

Leicht oxidierter Malzantrunk, mild, etwas herb. Das zunehmend trockene Malz wird schokoladig, die Herbe steigt nur minimal. Süßlich, zum Ende schokoladiger, das Bier wird intensiver und stößt die Wässrigkeit ab. Angenehm holzig-malziger Abgang, weich und süffig. Fast unbemerkt hat sich auch die Trockenheit wieder verabschiedet. Gelungen! 11/10/9/11/11/11

Clear, medium to dark reddish brown colour, with a creamy, tan head that almost survives as long as the beer itself, and that leaves a good deal of lacing on the glass. The aroma is raisins, molasses and dough. The taste is moderate sweet, with a filling sweet flavour of malts and alcohol, long aftertaste. Medium body, oily texture, average to soft carbonation. This is my first bock, but certainly not my last!  [33 cl bottle, from Vinmonopolet]
Den beste norske bokk.  Deilig øl med behagelig ettersmak.  Fin maltsmak og bra ettersmak.

Bottled from Vinmonopolet in Tromso.  Tried head-to-head with Mack Bok that had tootled a hundred metres down the road it came second.  Restrained caramel, which is not a bad thing, big grain but not so much poke.
Bottle. Pours clear dark amber with a white head.  Aroma is sweet with notes of bread and caramel. medium sweetness, lightly bitter.

Bottle at home.
Red-brown with a beige head, some lacings. Aroma moderate to heavy malty (caramel, roasted). Flavor moderate sweet and bitter. Medium body.

Pours very dark red colour with a beige foam. Pure malt aroma some dough and burnt caramel too. Heavy malty taste with some medium sweetness. Soft carbonation, oily feel, medium body. The sweetness persist in the after taste. One of the best norwegians? Among the good ones at least.

Bock--1998 11.2 oz. Bottle.  6.50% ABV.  (2.5 / 5.0)  Deep dark red color.  Fruity aroma and body, but not overly so.  Lager yeast off flavor present but not prominent.  A little fruity for my tastes as fruit overwhelms malt.  Sampled 11/21/1998.

Bock Beer--2002 11.2 oz. Green Extra Long Neck Bottle.  6.50% ABV.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Clear rich dark copper bronze color.  Lacy medium head.  Roasted mild hop front.  Smooth rich creamy thin dry sweet toffee cherry doughy biscuit body.  Balanced mild hop end.  Rich No Spice Juleol.  Sampled 5/15/2003.

Bottle, 2010-03-19, Göteborg
AR. fudge, caramell, plum
AP: dark amber brown, cremy ofwhite head
F: roasted malt, brulee pudding with caramel sauce, sweet and dry finish

Bottle from Vinmonopolet. Ive had this before, but since its been a while and I now have the policy of rating everything I drink, I thought it was time for a revisit. This is a classic bock from the Scandinavian tradition, and the only Norwegian beer to make it into Michael Jacksons classic "500"-collection, since brewers like Nøgne Ø at the time of writing (2000) had yet to reach international acknowledgment. Pours a very deep coppery brown with a small, quickly disappearing head. To my disappointment, a metallic "canned food"-smell which I mainly associate with over-aged lagers or commercial dunkels on can hits my nose immediately. Luckily, it disappears after a while, and my snifter fills up with lovely notes of nougat, raisins and a hint of red vinegar. Taste is caramel malt, raisins again, a hint of cherries and a fair amount of candy sugar. If it wasnt for the balancing sourness blending out all the sweets, itd be almost like a Belgian dubbel without the yeasty notes. Rather drinkable, and blended in a very nice way. Nothing formidable, but probably a good beer to drink with a variety of food. I liked this one.

33cl bottle from Vinmonopolet. Best before 2010-06-11. This was the last on the list of best beers brewed in Norway I hadnt tried so it was about time I tried it. It poured a dark reddish brown colour with a medium big white creamy head that settled down fast in the glass. The aroma is sweet and bordering on sickeningly sweet. Very sweet malty aroma. Some hints of wood. The flavour is also sweet, but not so much as the aroma, thankfully. The sweet malts are dominant, but theres also notes of caramel and brown sugar as well. Short aftertaste. A decent beer overall, but more of a ticker beer than something Im going to look for later.

Ive been wanting this beer ever since Michael Jackson presented it in one of his books.  Deep mahogany, initial aroma of wet grass and dank topsoil.  Once settled what remained was raspberry jam, port, and toasted wood.  Less complex in the sip, simple, dark, chocolate with a bit of grit.  Medium bodied and a little smoky in the finish.  Clean finish.

Bottled 330ml. -Reddish/brown coloured, medium to big sized off-white head, burnt sugar nose. Sweet malty, slight toffee and mild hoppy with some unpleasant metallic notes in the finish. Expected better beer.
Clear dark amber color with light brown head, nice smell of malts - tastes of roasted malt that lingers , low bitterness - Very nice and drinkable beer

30.08.2009, 0,33l Bottle. Almost black in colour. Head is two fingers thick and off-white. Aroma is rich malty and roasted. Sweet with roasted caramel. Very nice and good tasting bock. 

྿.01.2003: Mørk bokkøl som skummer godt. Lukten er preget av malt. Tydelig annerledes enn Frydenlunds. Smaken og ettersmaken er fyldig og markert med bitterhet og sødme)

0.33 cl bottle. Dark clear red. Medium lasting dense tan head.Dark ripen fruits, plum standing out, sweety roasted malt, burnt caramel. Disappointing flavor and mouthfeel, malt bitterness and malt sweetness not balanced, almost sticky feeling, bit nauseating. It gains few points more only because I bought it in North Cape!
Very pleasant bock. Rich aroma roasted raisins (?) and dark bread, again felt in the mouth. a good swallow balanced with the same roastish sweetness lingering softly. Recommended!

Bottle 33 Cl. Apperance; Dark dark red, clear with a light brown head that goes away pretty fast. Aroma; Some 
roasted malt and dark fruits. Flavor; Dark fruits with a light sweet aftertaste.
0,33 l bottle. Clear dark brown, with a small sized fine lazed head. Aroma of raisins and roasted malt.Gentle taste of caramel and spices, also some liquorice. Good bitteness

330 ml bottle. Clear, amber body with a firm, beige head. Aroma is subdued malty and caramel with a hint of roasted malt. Flavor is sweet malt and balanced bitter. Relatively light body, but well made.

0.33 l bottle. Mahagony color with creamy head. Sweetish, malty and caramelly aroma with prunes, raisins, chocolate and cherry. Toasty, nutty and toffeish flavor with chocolate,  prunes, raisins and figs. Nice soft and warming mouthfeel. Tasty, yet easy drinking and moreish.
Dark malts and toffee with warming alcohol. Herbs on aroma over mild malts and little hops.

Reddish brown appearance, medium beige top. Sweet and malty aroma with some caramel and liquorice. Flavor is mild and fruitful with caramel. Also some alcohol but it’s not disturbing. Smooth palate and medium body. Good and balanced beer for cold winter nights.

Appearance: Redish brown. Bit of head, short-lived.
Aroma: Malty. Alcohol. Hops and fruit.
Taste: Malt and hops. Alcohol. Bitter aftertaste. Bit of fruit.
Info: 330ml bottle, 7/1-2007, 129/500

Small head is blond beige and has big bubbles with lacing. Liquid is reddish brown and clear. Malty aroma has sweet caramel malts and rye bread. Grassy hops with some raisins. Begins with medium roasted malts and finishes as light bitter and caramel sweet. Quite rich maltiness. Medium sweet flavor with quite light bitteration. Medium bodied, texture is oily and turns to a bit sticky dry in the finish. Decent beer with malty body.

Decent enough beer, not overly sweet, but has an assertive maltiness.  Lots of caramel, with a hint of herbal spices and some dried fruits.  Not alot of complexity, but alot of drinkability.  Good session style.

Bought from the vinmonopolet. A reconmendation fra a mate. A sweetish beer, with lots of speicilty malts and dried fruits aromaes. Suppose to be the port of Norway. Not really port level, but still a great beer
33 cl bottle. Brown/reddish color. Big, off-white head. Dominated by sweet malt/caramell, but also dried fruits and maybe some spice. Ok bitterness.
Bottle @ Craigs house. hay, grass, brown, hazy, aminimal head, light sweetness, medium body,
Bottle at home ...  Deep brown slight red tinge ... deep roast malt ... soft little caramel roast malt ... little sweet little lager hop.

Bottle (33 cl) from Furseth, mange takk!. Clear deep reddish copper with a medium creamy off-white head. Roasted malt aroma, a bit syrupy, smooth mouthfeel, good balance. A bit one-dimensional but quite nice.

Clear dark brown. Rich dark malt nose for a Norweigian bock. Toasty thick bread pudding maltiness that surprises again in mouth as the palate feels quite dry despite the low-profile nature of the hops. Not very complex and not very fruity, but comfortable and expanding mouthfeel ensures the drinkability and interest. Good.

Date: 10/14/1999
Mode: Bottle
Source: Wild Wing Cafe, Marietta

dark brown with ruby highligts, whispy head, sweet malt aroma, rich malt flavor, lots of sweetness yet balanced with a bit of earthy peat character, touch of chocolate, malt finish
-------- />
Date: 05/04/2006
Source: aa

still all sweet with a bit of alcohol, dries up in the finish, 

Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.5/5.0Score: **4
-------- />
The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
Bottle thanks to ?, rbesg07. Aroma is sweet honey pale malts, biscuity raw malts. Taste is similar but the biscuit malt helps it out.

Bottle. Reddish brown with a creamy tan head. Roasted caramel aroma with some nuttiness. Nutty flavours blending well with caramel. Overall quite sweet, though the finish is slightly drier. Light body. Not bad.

Bottle. High creamy and lasting off-white head. Beautiful clear and ruby body. Roasted dand drybarley malt aroma with hay notes.Vineous as well.  Flavor of caramel and some spice I cannot quite figure out. Moderaltely carbonated and with a pleasant bitterness. Long aftertaste.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with a tan head. Malty aroma with a note of raisin. Nice malty flavour, slightly vinous. Medium bitterness.

330 ml bottle. Dark copper colour with a reddish hue. Crystal clear. Small white head. Licorice and a bit münchener malt aroma. Not much aroma to speak of. Watery texture and little body. I remember this bees being much maltier and a lot sweeter. Low on the hops. Very disappointing in fact. Will have to try it again next season.
In my opinion this is the best Norwegian dark bock. Powerful malt, but it is well balanced with the hops. My first choice for the creamcakes.
Amber of color with a beige head. An aroma of port and raisins. A nice flavor of plums, raisins and port.

Bottle. Clear amber red color with a average frothy fair lacing mostly lasting off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a short to average duration, (malt sweet). Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. Simple bock.
Bottle at Chris_O bottlefest 2007.  Clear russet/amber colour, beige head.  Slightly sticky, some toffee.  Slightly sticky.  Not bad.  Simple bock.
Bottle, 6.5%. Brown colour. Small lightl brown head. OK bready flavour with a hint of malt.

ChrisFest A beer I have wanted for some years. It is the first beer in Jacksons 500 Classic Brews. Sadly the best before date was 7 days ago, and it does smell and taste old. Toffee in a school blazer pocket. Sweet malty finish. Not the beer I was hoping to drink.
Bottle. Dark amber color. Good roasted malty and caramel aroma. Sweet caramel and toasted malty soft flavour. Short finish. Thanks to Yngwie.

A Mes rate: 33cl bottle at Chris Os extravaganza. Brown colour with a swiftly dissiapating tan head. Marmite, malt, wheat and straw. Flavour is similar with some extra sweetness. A lighly roasted character to it too. Not bad.

The head is nice, creamy and lasting. The aroma is malty/roasted malt. At first the flavour is rather sweet, but then its accompanied by a nice bitterness (an a brief watery feeling) , that has notes of hops, licorice and roasted malt. A nice surprise, but drink it cold, otherwise its too sweet.
Pours a dark amber with a small creamy head. Roasted and caramel malt aroma. Flavour also of roasted and caramel malt and ends up with a vinious feel. (Bottle)

Bottle. Pours a dark amber with a thin, but quite creamy head. Aroma has lots of malts - roasted and caramel. Flavour is sweet. Actually a quite complex set of flavours. Starts of as a malty sweetness, then turns slightly smoky and roasted. As it goes down a slight viniousness remains as well as a citric bitterness. A touch of metallic that will probably disappear as i heats up in the glass.
interesting aroma of malts and lettuce (?). Some dried fruit also. Taste is about the same, some plums and raisins also. A bit thin on the palate but well masked. A funky bock!!

Bottle. Pours deep amber with a small, lasting, creamy,  tan head. Strong aroma of dark malt and caramel. Taste is moderatly sweet and lightly bitter, dominated by malt, toffee and dark dried fruits. Surprisingly light-bodied. Very smooth and easy to drink. A nice bock.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2007 Smuggled by TimE back from Belmont Station in Portland about 4 years ago. I hope it didnt evolve a condom and him swallowing this. A decent bock and it meets everything the commerical description says. Page 10 of Michael Jacksons Great Beer Guide 190 out of 500 Classic Brews to go.
Bottle. Reddish dark brown with small beige haed. Malt, yeast and a light sweetness hits my nose. Flavour is vague with sweetness dominating and a vague bitter finish. Lacking a lot of potency.
Bottle at RBESG 2006. Some nice chocolate and malt in here, but a bit weaker and waterier than I was expecting.
bottle. I was surprised here. I didnt expect a lot, but i got a very good bock beer. amber colour with a decent white head. Complex aroma and taste of malts, fruits and spices.
(Bottle) Pours dark red. Aroma of unsweetened plums and some alcohol. A bit malty. Sweet dark flavour with malt and some chocolate. Sour hints. Small to medium body.

[Sampled at RGESG 2006]
Red amber. Small head.
Some frutiiness, but more of boiled vegetables.
AMber with a brownish head. Malty aroma with some chocolate and milky notes. Malty flavor, some chocolate here as well. Malty finish.
(Bottle on RBESG 2006) Clear red brown color, white head. Sweet malty scent, vegetable taste, also grainy and malty. Thin mouth feel. Normal/regular Aass is tons better!
33 cl bottle. Reddish brown colour with a nice head. Sweet malty aroma with note of caramel. Flavour of burned caramel and notes of malt and some hints of roastedness. Very nice endeed but not great.

Bottled. Very dark amber colour, small beige foamy head. Aroma is caramellish malty with weak hints of alcohol. Flavour is malty, metallic and some honey and weak hops in finish. Palate is a bit sticky. A good beer which is quite wellbalanced.

Dark redish brown with a creamy head.
Malt and chocolate notes. Medium body with some bitterness in the finish.

<!-- i -->Bottled<!-- /i -->.<!-- br -->
Dark nut brown, small creamy tan head. Roasted, woody and a bit sweet nose. Carbonated, roasted, some brown sugars in the finish, slightly metallic. Does not show its alcohol much.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2006 Bottle: Dark red colour, with a werry nice creamy light brown foam.
Aroma of maltynes,chocolateand smoouth bitternes in the end.
Medium body, with malt,chocolate.Smouth bitter finish.This is the best Bock beer in Norway,that´s my upinion.
Bottle. Brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is roasted caramel. Flavour is roasted caramel with some alcohol.

Last Friday eve (16.06.2006) I gave four Norwegian bock beers a try. Available were bocks from Aass, Mack, Borg and Frydenlund. Among them Aass Bock has the highest average score in RB and has been rated by more than 140, while the others have only around 20 ratings so far.
330ml bottle. Clear mahogany. Small off-white head. Slight lace. Strong malted coat nose. Malt, bread and raisin in flavour. A bit watery. A complex brew, but not the best among Norwegian bocks in my opinion.
Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Heavy malty aroma. Little hopp detected. A bit sweet flavor, average finish. Oily palate, not my favorite bock but ok.
Quite complex flavours, sweet malt and liberal use of hops. A rich beer with a bitter finish. Toffee sweetness, citrusy hops tending towards grapefruit.

Bottle. RBESG, August 2005. Mid brown colour. Quite fizzy. Strong bready malt aroma with nutty overtones. Some raisiny fruit and more toasty malt on the palate. Not too sweet, although it could do with a bit more hop presence in my view. Light body.  A smooth and easy drinking bock.
Bottle 0,33l. Clear dark amber. Creamy tanned head. Some malty smell. Well balanced with taste variations all the way. Medium body. A bit too carbonated.
Poured a clear amber color.  Plums and other fruits in the aroma.  Flavor was malty with some sweet raisins.  Clean finish.  I think this one was aged, not sure how long, but still nice.

Big tan, creamy head; clear dark red body. Tight, not too strong, harmonic aroma of chocolate, some coffee, and, treacle. Deep and firm taste of sweet malts, notes of chocolate and coffee, maybe burnt bread. Almost oily mouthfeel. Very nice lightly burnt aftertaste lingers on. Taste is as harmonic as the aroma. Very good, if a bit mild. This has to be easily the best Norwegian bock.
UPDATED: JAN 5, 2007 Bottle. Dark brown with beige head. Sweet and caramel taste with some alcohol. Balanced beer, and to my opinion the best Norwegian Bock. (050919)

Ruby colour with white head. Big, sweet aroma. Moderate malty taste with just enough hoppiness for balance. In my limited experience, that is not always the case with this style. Also quite thick on the palate, whic I enjoy.
A brown beer with a disappearing light brown head. The aroma is sweet and slighlty roasted, and so is the flavor though here combined with notes of caramel.
RBESG05: Brown with a tan head. Balanced chocolate and nut flavour all the way through. Rather subtle and a little bland, but still quite enjoyable.
Bottle. Brown colour with a baige head. Caramel malty fruity aroma and a sweet caramel malty taste. Medium body and a light sweet finish.

Bottled. RBESG -05. 
Copper colour. Almondy nose along with a dash of caramel. Clean bock with notes of almonds and sugars. Pretty light body though.
Dark mahogany colour, thin off white head. Dark fruit nose. Malty, earthy flavour with hints of brown sugar. Warming alcohol feeling.
Bottle @ RBESG2005. Sweet and malty aroma, with hints of alcohol and a little metal. Dark brown body, with a small tan head. Light malty flavor, ends rather sweet. A bit thin bodied.

Bottled.
Brown coured with an off white head.
Aroma of dark bread and dried fruits.
Sweet flavour of dark bread and dried fruits with notes of alcohol.
A bit watery, but a nice bock.
Poured a nice dark(almost black) body with a off-white creamy head.  Notes of chocolate and malt on the nose and hops, molosses, roasted malts on the tongue.  Great beer.  Wish I could still get it!

Bottle - trade with Sigmund (Cheers).  A dark brown coloured beer with russet hues.  The aroma is full, sweet and malty with chocolate notes.  The taste is heavy malts with brown bread characters.  A very tasty beer verging on German Doppelbock qualities rather than the sweetness of some Bocks.
Roasty sweet malts and a generous but not heavily sweet body. Satisfying and highly drinkable. A Scandanavian star worth stocking up on.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2005 (Bottle 33 cl) Very dark with a reddish tint. Pronounced maltiness ad caramel in both nose and flavour with some sweetness in a fine balance with the hops. I also detect a touch of licorice. An excellent beer. (Export version is only 6,3% ABV) 220201 and 290903

Poured a nice dark brow with red highlights, aroma of coffee and malt. Nice tanish head lasted a little. Good full feel. Burnt, roasted malts and grains maybe even molasses. Slight hops kick. Good brew.

(on bottle, thx Sigmund for this and the other  bocks of Norway)very dark brown, close to black beer.Has a wonderfull sent of freshly roasted dark malts, straight of the pan. Very smooth to drink, a bit creamy, witch is a good thing in my book. Not very high carbonated and no bitter hopping tat all. Wood and a dry feeling in the finish, and theres some hopping now, just to make you have another one.
Tried at O.C.  Very good Bock Beer.  Roast and Chocolate Taste.  Nice Even Taste.
a really great bock. Ive had a aass jouleus before, but this was really amazing. great chocolate and roasted tastes. A nice blend of hops to even the taste out, one of my favorite bocks ive had.

Worth as try if you like bocks, but if you are accustomed to the German variety, this one may leave you a bit disappointed.  Rather thin in flavor, aroma, and overall appearance.  Still generally worthwhile.

A very typical example of the style, only a bit better. Actually, it's a very good example.

Pours a brown color with a decent head leaving some lacing. As it warms, it reminds me of a cola that has lost the carbonation.

Smells of a toasted malt with a faint hint of hops.

Taste is typical. Again, toasted (okay, roasted) malts. Some fruits are present as well. Coffee teases the tongue.

Mouthfeel is better than average as it's a bit fuller than usual and it has a nice mineral mouthfeel. Drinkability is pretty good as well. 

This is one of the best bocks I've had and well worth the search.

Redbrown.
Fruity aroma with tones of licorice,chocolate fudge,prunes and red meat.
Fruity flavor with tones of kernels, meat and blackcurrant. Tiny bitterness. Definitely the best norwegian beer.

Bottled: Dark ruby red. Thin fine head. Medium lasting. Malty, fruity and some cocoa ntes in the aroma. Reminds me a lot of a good dobbelbock. Malt, and some fruit and cocoanotes in the flavour. Very thin compared to the aroma. Sweet aftertaste with no bitterness at all. Dies quickly on the palate.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2004 Dark brown appearance with a red tint. Aroma is chocolate and caramel quite a nice sniffer. Flavor is sweet with some caramel and chocolate notes. A slight bitterness in the finish. I was nervous buying this one because of the green bottles with dust on them but it turned out to be quite nice. I would make a childish comment on the name of this beer but I will refrain. NICE AASS! Sorry I couldn't resist.

Dark amber, near brown coloured body with ruby highlights and a medium-sized tan head. Aroma of cherries, nuts, malt, metal and a slight sourness. Medium-bodied; Sweet initial flavour with a metallic overtone and a pleasant malt backbone. Aftertaste shows a lot of the metallic character with a bit of the fruityness and a moderate amount of the sweetness. A bit too stagnant and musty for my tastes, but all-in-all, not a horrendous beer! I bought this twelve ounce bottle at Beers of the World in Rochester, New York and sampled it on 09-December-2003.

33 cL bottle, tulip glass, 55 degrees F.  Tight, tan, frothy, creamy head diminishes quickly and sits on a brown body that's neary opaque, but not murky.  Cookie, milk chocolate malt (M); prune, ruby port, oak aromas.  Heavily sweet flavor becomes a moderately sweet, lightly bitter, lightly acidic finish.  Medium-heavy body, soft carbonation, velvety texture.  The bottom line is: I'm not sure I really understand bocks...then again I'd like to try a fresher one.

Sweet, but almost cardboardy malts and hints of grassy hops in the nose.  Jaymobrown  and I discussed how we both describe the taste as earthy, but in an 'earthworm' sort of way.  Have we both eaten earthworms at some point?  Cardboard taste is light but starts to get in the way of the sweetness and lingering soy notes. NOt actually offensive, but nothing I would have again.  Worlds smallest goat on the label.  I would have gladly let it finish my bottle.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2005 Dark reddish-brown body, creamy beige head, and mild carbonation. Nose is of caramel and some European aromatic hops. Smooth but somewhat syrupy malt profile. This beer is my notion of a bock. In that sense, this beer is a prototype to me. I was happily enjoying this beer on my porch when a monstrous 2 inch long fly landed on my arm, initiating a spastic reflex that spilled about 4 oz. on my lap. Warning: flies are attracted to Aass.
This tastes like soy sauce left outside in a tub of meat and fried vegetables.  More earthen gritty texture, and some dough, yeast flavors.

Pours a slightly transparent red brown. . . Minimal bubbly head.  Nice malty, hop aroma, with some alochol, almond, coffee and chocolate.  Palate is solid, but not outstanding, some chewy rye dough malt, bananas, toffee and bark.  Lingering bitterness that is very plesant.
I just picked this up because I've never had anything from Norway before. This is amazing. Wow... sweet malts in the aroma nice bitters very nice. Sweet caramel as well. Toffy colour

was ready for something great here...thought of it as rather average all around and extremely unexciting.  had more alcohol sting and slowness of drinking than i expected.  don't know what a norwegian bock tastes like, is this it?
no 'ass', but not the biggest loss in the world if it's missed.
Dark amber color. Strong roasted malt and caramel nose. Quite heavy body with a touch of acidity; a lot of caramel. Reminds me some old Swiss dunkel.

i like the label: it's a goat lapping at a mug of sudsy beer, but the neat thing is that the mug and goat are the same size, which means either a really big glass of beer or a really small goat--either way you've got quite a novelty. golden honey hues were merged with aged chestnut to create a pleasing effulgence in such a dark beer (yes, it's true: i just wanted to use the word 'effulgence'). a delicate smear of hazelnut foam serves as an ample medium to etch ever changing scripts of lace.  aroma is a bock-scotch ale amalgam of sweet woody malts, notes of dried peach, well oiled leather, cedar mulch, cola. on the tongue it's silky and sweet, like lightly brown-sugared toffee toasted pecans,  some burnt edges, more cola with moderate bitterness. the only fault was a couple thread-bare spots where a bit too much of that fine norwegian water showed through.
Light caramel and raisin aroma. Dark brown, light brown head, good lace. Sweet, caramel, bit fruity, soft. Short finish. Reminds me of the German style bocks. Nice.

This is the first bock and first beer from Norway that I have tried. This one pours a clear, deep, reddish brown color with a small, mostly diminishing, off-white head. The aroma is malty with hints of caramel and licorice. It has a medium to full body with moderate carbonation. The flavor is entirely made up of malts with a lingering sweetness and hints of caramel and dark fruits. The finish is malty sweet. Quite a nice little treat.
Brown and clear with a small head.  Aroma of a brewpub.  Barley malt and bread flavor.  Dry finish.

I am not a big fan of bocks but here is a real stand out. Sweet and burnt brown sugar tastes stay in the background and let the hops and malt through. Cool picture on label reminds me of my high school girlfriend.

Toffee and licorice aromas, a bit burned sweetness.
Deep red brown, small head which disappears fast.
Licorice prevails in the taste, lingering sweet malt in the aftertaste.
A bit too thin mouthfeel, which on the other hand makes it easy to drink.
Tak Sigmund!
Lighter brown with a hint of red in it.  Small head that doesn't linger long.  A little thin for the style, but a decent malt sweetness.  Pretty decent.  Not a bad one to have a few of!

Jewel-like ruby color with a thin, quickly dissipating head.  Thin, winey nose.  I thought this was too thin.  Almost tasted like sugar water.  There were some dark sweet flavors, but mostly alcohol and water.
Solid bock. Good malty flavor - hint of raisins.  A little bit on the watery side though - ding on the palate.  Nice ruby red appearance. Enjoyable malty aroma.

Nice grainy, bock-malty aroma.  Dk brown with slight creamy head.  Dunno what they were thinking with the green bottle with the pink label (US version.) Mellow malt, grain, raisin and tobacco flavor.  A dark syrup note to it.  Grainy characteristics that I associate with altbier.  Clean, grain-bitter finish, without the metal edge that ruins so many bocks.  Decent enough.
having not had the most favourable introduction to norwegian beer, this was a pleasant surprise. roasted pear and salted licorice aroma. burnt amber. quite a mild bock but in a good way
Simple and straightfoward, this is a textbook example of what I expect a bock beer to taste like.  Slightly nutty and smoky, but on the thin side in palate.  Overall, a tasty "session" beer.
Looks great when poured into the glass, but there's little aroma and flavor.  It just seemed watered down to me.
This is smooth and subtle.  Some caramel, cloves, and a mild sweetness, make this easy to drink ale quite enjoyable.  In my opinion, this is better than aventinus
Extreme maltiness and an essence of caramel.  Easy to drink bock, with low alcohol content.  Dark amber, some lacing around the sides of my glass.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2003 This is not dopplebock, this is the Scandi version of a dark/bock lager. Candied flavors help cover high alcohol without getting that too much malt wash out, makes for a silky body which to me is a plus. The Danish, Norweig and Austians are often overlooked for there contributions to the worlds great lagers. Everybody wants to fit them into german styles and they are hybrid styles there own. LOVE THIS STUFF!!!!
Not a bad bock.  Not very hoppy.
light black. a nice maltly, robust but laid back bock.
Dark brown. No head to speak of. Malty aroma, to go with a very malty, somewhat sweet flavor. I agree with earlier reviewers--it makes a nice change from heavily hopped ales.
Color is a beautiful dark red-brown.  Taste has a little skunk at first then has nice smooth malty aftertaste.  Alittle expensive .  Wouldnt buy again

Very nice lace, dense sheets between erratic lumpy spots.  Reddish brown body.  Loaded with barley, lots of barley.  Some subdued floral hoppiness, but barley all around.  It is a robust brew, with decent balance.  The Green glass doesnt help though.
Pours dark like a cola with a medium beige head. Nose is sweet and malty. Flavor: Start is sweet, finish somewhat dry. Thin mouth feel, but tasty and drinkable.
Very nice roasted palate and a wonderfully malty aroma.  The body is too thin and could be sweeter, but overall, a respectably decent brew.
Just enough malt, nice sweetness. A great drinkable bock

As is pretty obvious, this is a rather malty beer.  The aroma is off dry biscuits, shortcake and wheat bread.  The flavors are still quite malty, with a touch of sweetness.  A very nice beer, better than I expected.  I will concur, and say this is a wonderful change to the many ales Ive been drinking recently.
Strong malt in nose and flavor with some hints of chocolate very nice change from the ales ive been having lately

Feelings for this have wavered over the years. First found it in a deli in Manhattan 20 some odd years ago and thought it was the best. A few years later feelings slid. I enjoy the maltiness and break from my standard fare of mega hopped beers. Very nice.
A fine beer that deserves its high ratings here.
Barley aroma. Amber with hints of read, no head. Malt and grain flavor. Smooth and creamz, nice
Light nose, dark brown color, fresh barley malt taste - light malt extract. Somewhat sugary too. Full body and a clean palette.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2003 traveling along a sea of creamy cherries...riding a raft of licorice root in a storm of raining cola drops.. Metallic cherry scrapings..licorice hail..smooth but thick but refreshingly not so thick..all at the same time
Sweet, malty aroma almost toffee-like. Very smooth creaminess and a clean finsh.
I liked the appearance of this beer.  It is more like a dark-brown lager to me.  It has a toffee like taste and a very smooth creaminess.
This stuff tastes like aass. Sorry obvious joke. This has a nice caramel malty flavor, but dissappears in my mouth. It does seem to go well with heavy food.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2003 Re-rate:  Haven"t encountered the wateriness noted below in subsequent samples. Major boost in order

Beautiful garnet color with very nice dark fruit aroma framed with alcohol.  Delicious bock flavors of heavitly carmelized malt.  Comes up short, however.  Much like ordering an Optimator-and-water.  Not bad, but watery palate reminds me that better dunkel bock is available.
Malted milk nose with some winey malt.  Fluffy off white head.  Assertive malts w/o too much alcohol.  Slightly sweet with a malted milk ball finish, good but not
Nice malty aroma, some apple/fruit and burnt coffee.  Very drinkable, typical smooth sweet bock mouthfeel.  Complex but distant flavour.
I didnt find this beer to be interesting at all.  It was malty, definately a bock.  But not a whole lot of body or flavor.
Malty aroma.Deep tawney appearance.Creamy, burnt malt, winey flavour.Dark malt finish.It was a bit too malty for me I may have drank this one too cold.

Dark red color with a creamy tan top.  Aroma is amazing, chocolate with nuts, plenty of malt and caramel.  Body is nicely sweet with a great chewy malt presence.   Notes of licorice, nuts and a touch of smoke make this a top notch bock!  Light iron notes in the palate detract points making it a few points below celebrator.  Excellent.
Smells like someones making fudge.   Reddish-brown body, chewy, burnt caramel, molasses, semi-sweet chocolate.   Finish is slightly bitter and clean.   Tasty on this cold and wet Ohio October night.

Deep red brown color. Medium foamy head. Coffee and chocolate aroma. Full bodied bock. Malty and hoppy. Malts are slightly sweet. Coffee and chocolate flavor. Nice balance. Full flavor. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and slightly dry. Aftertaste is slightly bitter, a very slight alcohol bite in the aftertaste. Nice bock.

red-brown color.  not much nose.  medium to thick body - but not as malty as other bocks.  flavors are subtle - lightly roasted barley, bit of dark fruit, touch of candy-sugar sweetness.  only slightly bitter.  definitely a bit different than usual for the style - almost like a bock with belgian influences.  the whole thing works quite well though - very nice.

Pours much like a cola, but with a creamier, more lasting head; translucent.  I found the nose big and sweet and earthy; flavor is a good match, slightly burnt and smoked in the middle and somewhat acidic and hoppier at the end.  Very warming.  Well-above average bock.

Beatiful red-brown colour. Nice, slightly off-white head. Not a particularly big aroma. Quite firm and malty, sweetish however, a tad sticky, slight acidic/ bitter finish, caramelly, raisiny quite nice, leaves a nice flavour in your mouth.
Deep mahogany, minimal head. Dark chocolate, raisins, cherries, marzipan, a hint of espresso. Truly wonderful.

Sweet, molasses aroma, deep garnet, tiny toffee head. Extra sweet malt and caramel flavour, good bitterness in the after taste. Sweet, creamy, syrupy, very little carbonation, almost like a malt beverage? Very enjoyable though!
Attractive dark brown color, nice spicy aroma. Great malt flavor.  Anise and liquorice as well as cara malt sweet/roasty flavors.  A gorgeously malty bock.
Creamy and delicious.
Good bock. Light carbination creamy smooth with roasty malt flavor.

Though Id hate to live in the socialist utopia that is modern Norway, I could perhaps stomach paying 50% of my wages to the State if Aass was my local brewery.  Tastes more like a doppelbock to me, yet no alcohol is evident.  Its fairly sweet throughout.  Who knew the Norwegians had such a winner on their hands.

Candied ruby-amber look with moderate cream head and some carbonation. Small, clean chocolate malt aroma. Unfortunately, this beer has a very canny-metallic-tinny flavor to it--maybe this was from the cap--but the canny character dominated and the malt was kept subtle and secondary.
Nice Norwegian Bock, true to the style this beer is flavorful and smooth.  Good clean and crisp feel in the mouth and a pleasant after taste.

Riding orse back, Norwegian style, you travel a good deep range of malty complexity.  In a laid bock, understated way, the beer brings to mouth soft dark fruits (figs?), carmelity, and drier java edges to keep things honest and prevent cloying.  A little more exotic than your run of the mill midwestern bock, so it gets points, but the taste seems less big and bold than Id like.

one of my favorites i will take this over most german bocks i dont think anything may have changed though it seems just a bit lighter in body. beautiful maltiness well balanced seem like just a bit of licorice in the flavor which i find likeable
Caremel matly aroma, nice creamy mouthfeel, good roasty malt flavor.
Thick, dark, very drinkable beer.  Definitely a big beer with a lot of taste.  Beautiful mixture of sweetness and hops.
One of the rare bocks that I can drink more than one of in a sitting
roasty all malt aroma.  big and slightly chewy.  im having trouble figuring it out but I enjoy every minute of it.

Deep garnet color with a diminutive head that didnt last too long.  Aroma is straight malt - caramel and toffee.  Initial sip is also big on malt and the beer tends to become more complex as it warms by gaining in body and creaminess.  No discernable hop content.  Finishes lightly sweet and has a creamy aftertaste that coats the mouth.  Enjoyable.

OK, I admit it, I couldnt stop laughing at the name of this beer.  Too bad I cant find a bar that serves it so I can say gimme an Aass Bock.  Beyond the unfortunate name, there is much to be admired, a malty aroma (no descernable hops anywhere though) a creamy smooth, sweet flavor and a malty aftertaste.  I would have liked a bit of hop flavor though, otherwise quite nice.

PS: since I wrote this Ive gotten a number of e-mails telling me the proper way to pronounce the name of this beer.  Sorry, but the Beavis in me cant help but snicker.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing.
Body is clear medium orange-brown. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted
dark bread, nutty, roasted grain, mild coffee, caramel), with notes of
toffee and vanilla. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish
is lightly sweet, moderately bitter, lightly acidic. Medium body, creamy
texture, lively carbonation, lightly astringent. Complex malty aroma,
good flavor balance, and a nice mouthfeel.
Re-Rate 06/10/02: Deep garnet, large beige head, decent lace. Nose malt, hints of caramel, front is sweet, the top is light, the finish is dry, acidic, lightly hopped, drinkable, but a little Weak.
Nice reddish colour. Mild caramel taste and some fruityness. Probably the best beer of Norway, but not the king of bocks.

This beer is outstanding!  By far, the best bock I have ever had.  Pretty orange-maroon color, small head.  Aroma of roasted malty caramel.  Taste was excellent...somewhat complex for a bock....molasses, caramel, rounded out perfectly with a crisp hop finish....this beer kicks aass!

Cola like appearance/color. Pale brown head - loose and carbonated - dissipates quickly. Decent aroma - deep roasted malt. Flavors seemed very subtle - malt dominates, not really sweet, didnt notice any hops. Overall seemed a bit light in style, flavor and body.

Reddish brown body with a small head. Nose is sweet and malty and quite enticing. Has a good full, buttery mouthfeel. Flavor rivals Celebrator--sweet and malty with just a touch of bitterness, with a complex array of chocolatey/toffee/coffee notes.
Probably the best Norwegian beer (of any style) you can get. The benchmark of a Norwegian bock.

Very nice!!  I proclaim that from now on, I will not make immature jokes about the name Aass.  Just kidding, I will.  What if you crossed Aass Bock and Hair of the Dog?  Anyway, I LOVED the appearance - rich, creamy head, dark color.  Nice caramel in the aroma which followed through well into the flavor, maltiness, sweet.  Attention Shiner, Ziegen, Saxer, Michelob: THIS is a real bock!!

Deep brownish-orange with not much head.  Smells very sharp, sweet, lemony, and malty.  Flavor is quite sweet and extremely malty.  Get some hints of lemon juice and a mouthfeel of unfiltered mineral water.  Hops dry the finish somewhat.  A decent bock, though not as robust and hearty as expected.
A decent bock - moderate sweetness, robust maltiness.  Nice lingering head, deep brown/ruby color.  No bitterness/hops to speak of.
Red-cola color; Head was eggshell colored and dense; Clean, malt aroma. Appropriate mouthfeel. A bit metallic (tinny). No alcohol detected. Amazingly mundane.

Norways Oldest Brewery - Medium bodied bock beer with a proliferation of sweet malt flavors. Kind of thin bodied and subtle in its flavors. Mild hopping. Finishes with a pronounced lager yeast flavor. Not bad - definatley something different.
While I didnt like their pilsner because of the vanilla flavor in it, the toffee flavor in this bock makes it simply excellent.  A truly great bock.
Dark brown, with a somewhat foamy head.  A sweet and malty nose almost toffeelike.  Smooth and creamy feel with classic bock qualities.  A classic in the style.
Ruby brown color with a creamy head, malty aroma, and a smooth drink from start to finish. Not as flavorful as some Ive had, but still nice. Very hard to come by in Portland though.

Starting to get a little skunky here.  Thats the bad thing about getting beer from other countries.  This is definitly a smoother bock than usual. If you can get past the skunky part,  then this is a decent beer but Im sure its a lot better fresh in Norway.
This and the Julol are the best of Aass.   Malty with a touch of sweet.  Clean and well made.  Not as robust as one might hope for a bock, but by itself a very good drink.

browb red color, light brown head with some lacing.  lots of malt here with a pleasant lingering caramel aftertaste.

very good bock.
Brown-red. Big soft maltiness, lingering toffee flavour. A well balanced bock beer of high class.
An extremely delicious Bock.  Beautiful color, generous head a nice finish.  The alcohol is hardly noticable.
This is a great Bock Beer! Very easy to drink. If you like Bock styles, you must try this one!
Beautiful all the way around.  One of my favorite beers.
Full-bodied, sweet, soft taste of black currants and liquorice. Long aftertaste.

When I saw the green glass bottle I thought it odd that a bock beer would be packaged that way. Then when I opened the bottle I was disappointed with the aroma and thought the beer had gone skunky; but when I tasted it, wow! Delicious malty body with yeasty flavors reminiscent of home brew -but better. Lovely deep ruby color but the head was not long lasting. Quite strong but very flavorful and enjoyable. This is a good sipping beer for special occasions. Nice.

I had this and Old Peculiar at the same sitting and I dont think I would be able to tell the difference in a taste test. Ill rate this without looking at what I rated that, but they should be the same. It was a nice solid bock beer. I could drink this all night.
pretty good taste for a aassbrewer
Absolutely beautiful color.  Overall a very nice Bock.
Its like candy for my eyes, nose, and mouth.
Toasted or burnt caramel flavor and a great mouthfeel. Nice looking and tasting.
Overall a good, but not great beer
Reminds me of a maibock. Soft malt flavors, well balanced.
The best Norwegian beer I have tastet.
Perhaps the best Norwegian beer. Drink this beer temperate!

UPDATED: APR 4, 2005 While I dont agree with Shadallion who said this is the king of bock, I must admit that this was by far the best norwegian beer Ive tasted until the apparition of the Nogne O beers - dark ruby colour, fine head, caramel, malty and sweet.
Very nice bock, with full dark fruit flavors, but all subtle.  It had an amazingly soft and creamy mouthfeel.  Nice sweet, fruity aroma.  Not the best from Aass, but a very good beer.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2005 Everything that Samuel Adams Triple Bock should have been. Rich pruneish nose. Tastes like a fine after-dinner brandy. Full bodied and rounded out with a roasted maltiness. Prescence and kick of the alcohol becomes apparent in the finish. Excellent! Give me some more of that Aass!!!
This the king of bocks.  Smooth, creamy and delicous.  Not as challenging as dopples, so a new beer drinker should start here. A bottle-conditioned twang takes it to a new level. Awesome beer.

This beer tastes and smells like aass.    Ok now that I got that horrible pun out of the way...    This oh so bubbling lager has a clear amber colour and a somewhat creaming taste.    There is a nice little white head constantly on top of the brew.  The taste was somewhere between chocolate and apples with a roasted coffee finish. Green bottles are very cool and this bottle is no exception.    The shape is very neat.   One problem my Aass was slightly skunky due, no doubt, to the semi-transparent glass.
Middle of the road. Little head, yet quite carbonated.
UPDATED: DEC 1, 2003 lightish example, with only slight toffeeish notes, a dash of bitter chocolate, and more carbonation than would be expected in a bock.
